Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: It was a Sunday morning, and the salon was already buzzing. My regular client, Mrs. Lee, smiled as she settled into my chair. “Just a little trim on the fringe, please,” she said, her tone gentle as always. I glanced at the clock—service at church would start in thirty minutes, and I was supposed to help set up for the community lunch afterward. My pastor had reminded me last week how important it was to be present, not just for worship but for fellowship, too. But Mrs. Lee was a loyal client, and I prided myself on making sure everyone left my chair happy. She hesitated, then asked if I could adjust her fringe just a bit more. I could see she was nervous about it, and I knew how much she trusted me. My hands hovered over her hair, my mind torn. If I rushed, I might disappoint her. If I stayed, I’d be late for church—again. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt my heart race as I tried to decide what to do next.
